unnormalised: Char Dham Yatra registrations have begun! The Uttarakhand govt. officially opened online portals on 15/04/2024 for those planning to visit Kedarnath, Badrinath, Yamunotri, and Gangotri. Last year saw a record no. of pilgrims, and officials are expecting even more this year, especially with improved road connectivity to Hemkund Sahib. The yatra season usually starts around May, depending on when the temples open their doors.
normalised: Char Dham Yatra registrations have begun! The Uttarakhand government officially opened online portals on fifteenth April two thousand and twenty four for those planning to visit Kedarnath, Badrinath, Yamunotri, and Gangotri. Last year saw a record number of pilgrims, and officials are expecting even more this year, especially with improved road connectivity to Hemkund Sahib. The yatra season usually starts around May, depending on when the temples open their doors.

unnormalised: Folks planning the trip should register ASAP on the official website, which is uttarakhandtourism.gov.in. You'll need documents like Aadhaar card no. and a recent photo. Remember to get a medical check-up beforehand, especially if you're travelling with elderly relatives; the altitude can be tough, reaching up to 3,583 meters at Kedarnath. Pre-planning and booking accommodations in advance is recommended, particularly around popular spots like Joshimath, as hotels get fully booked quickly.

unnormalised: This year, authorities have preponed the opening of registration to manage the pilgrim flow better and avoid the chaos seen in previous years. They are also working on improving facilities along the routes, like adding more toilets and rest stops. Plus, they are deploying more medical teams at key points. Don't forget to check the weather forecast before you go; sudden changes are common in the Himalayas!

unnormalised: For those who prefer a less strenuous journey, helicopter services are available from places like Dehradun to Kedarnath. A one-way ticket costs around Rs. 7000-8000 per person. Also, remember to respect the local customs and traditions during your visit. Dress modestly, avoid loud noises inside the temples, and dispose of waste responsibly. Keep the mountains clean, guys!
